Extract Kinship

Watal M. Iwasaki

2019-02-18

Source: vignettes/kinship.Rmd
kinship.Rmd

Run simulation:

library(dplyr)
library(tekkamaki)

result = tekka('--seed=42 -y100 -l5') %>% print()
# # A tibble: 1 x 2
#   sample_family        demography          
#   <list>               <list>              
# 1 <tibble [2,698 × 6]> <tibble [1,755 × 4]>
sample_family = result$sample_family[[1L]] %>% print()
# # A tibble: 2,698 x 6
#    id    father_id mother_id birth_year location capture_year
#    <chr> <chr>     <chr>          <dbl>    <dbl>        <int>
#  1 12    0         0                  0        1           NA
#  2 13    0         0                  0        1           NA
#  3 11    12        13                 9        1           NA
#  4 15    0         0                  0        1           NA
#  5 16    0         0                  0        1           NA
#  6 14    15        16                 8        1           NA
#  7 10    11        14                17        0           NA
#  8 19    0         0                  0        1           NA
#  9 20    0         0                  0        1           NA
# 10 18    19        20                 9        1           NA
# # … with 2,688 more rows
demography = result$demography[[1L]] %>% print()
# # A tibble: 1,755 x 4
#     year location   age count
#    <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#  1     4        0     4  1000
#  2     5        0     5   635
#  3     6        0     6   400
#  4     6        2     1  1146
#  5     7        0     7   275
#  6     7        2     1  1659
#  7     7        2     2   209
#  8     7        3     2   206
#  9     8        1     8   166
# 10     8        2     1  1614
# # … with 1,745 more rows

Extract kinship with degree≤4:

kinship = find_kinship(sample_family, 4L) %>% print()
# # A tibble: 5 x 5
#   from  to    path   degree label
#   <chr> <chr> <chr>   <int> <chr>
# 1 1     1127  1100_1      4 HC   
# 2 1809  2567  1100_1      4 HC   
# 3 2322  2602  110_1       3 HUN  
# 4 2412  2567  1000_1      4 <NA> 
# 5 2412  2640  1000_1      4 <NA>

Bind other information to kinship data.frame:

sampled = sample_family %>%
  dplyr::filter(!is.na(capture_year)) %>%
  dplyr::transmute(id, location, capture_year, age = capture_year - birth_year) %>%
  print()
# # A tibble: 20 x 4
#    id    location capture_year   age
#    <chr>    <dbl>        <int> <dbl>
#  1 1            0           95     6
#  2 1127         1           95    11
#  3 1269         0           95     0
#  4 1730         1           95     0
#  5 1809         0           96     0
#  6 1992         1           96     0
#  7 2159         0           96     5
#  8 2241         1           96     8
#  9 2272         1           97     0
# 10 2322         0           97     0
# 11 2412         0           97     7
# 12 2437         1           97     9
# 13 2449         1           98     0
# 14 2479         0           98     0
# 15 2516         1           98    10
# 16 2532         0           98     5
# 17 2567         1           99     0
# 18 2602         1           99    10
# 19 2608         0           99     5
# 20 2640         0           99     0

kinship %>%
  dplyr::left_join(sampled, by = c(from = "id")) %>%
  dplyr::left_join(sampled, by = c(to = "id"), suffix = c("_from", "_to"))
# # A tibble: 5 x 11
#   from  to    path  degree label location_from capture_year_fr… age_from
#   <chr> <chr> <chr>  <int> <chr>         <dbl>            <int>    <dbl>
# 1 1     1127  1100…      4 HC                0               95        6
# 2 1809  2567  1100…      4 HC                0               96        0
# 3 2322  2602  110_1      3 HUN               0               97        0
# 4 2412  2567  1000…      4 <NA>              0               97        7
# 5 2412  2640  1000…      4 <NA>              0               97        7
# # … with 3 more variables: location_to <dbl>, capture_year_to <int>,
# #   age_to <dbl>
